importantDates.descriptionOfWhyDateIsRelevant: The date of the crash and the subsequent investigation update reflects the ongoing public interest in aviation safety following a similar incident last year.

The 2024 crash involving a similar Hawker 800XP during a stall test flight provides a direct historical precedent for the current crash, highlighting recurring safety concerns in business jet operations.

importantTimeframes.descriptionOfWhyTimeFrameIsRelevant: The plane departed Battle Creek Executive Airport at 5:08 p.m., marking the start of a test flight that ended in a rapid descent and crash.
The plane plunged in less than 20 minutes, with a descent rate peaking at 24,000 feet per minute, indicating a catastrophic failure in flight control.

keyTakeAways: A private business jet, registered XA-JMR and Mexican-registered Hawker 800XP, crashed during a test flight near Lansing, Michigan, killing all three on board.
The pilots reportedly requested a block altitude to manage flight operations, but failed to respond to air traffic control’s repeated attempts to assist.
The National Transportation Safety Board (NTSB) has opened an investigation into the crash, noting parallels with a similar business jet crash in February 2024.
The flight was part of a post-maintenance test flight conducted by Duncan Aviation, which maintains the aircraft and employs two pilots and a maintenance representative.
Preliminary tracking data shows a sudden and extreme descent from 15,000 feet to ground level in under a minute, suggesting a potential stall or loss of control.
The aircraft had not been flown since March 25, indicating possible maintenance or system issues that may have contributed to the incident.
A 2024 crash involving a similar Hawker 800XP during a stall warning system test flight raises concerns about recurring safety failures in business aviation.

summaryOfNewsArticle: A private Hawker 800XP business jet, registered XA-JMR and Mexican-registered, crashed during a test flight near Lansing, Michigan on October 17, 2025, killing all three on board — two pilots and a maintenance representative. The plane departed Battle Creek Executive Airport at 5:08 p.m. and climbed to 15,000 feet before experiencing a sudden and catastrophic descent, reaching a rate of 24,000 feet per minute in under a minute. Air traffic control audio captures pilots repeatedly requesting stall recovery, and the controllers attempted to reach them seven times without success. Duncan Aviation, which conducted the maintenance and operated the flight, has opened a support channel for affected families. The National Transportation Safety Board has launched an investigation, citing a prior similar crash in February 2024 involving a Hawker 800XP during a stall test flight. The aircraft had not flown since March 25, 2025, raising concerns about system reliability and maintenance integrity.
title: Deadly plane crash in Michigan mirrors similar business jet crash last year
